Review title: A cure for a mid-life crisis? It's worth a shot!
Review_body:
After giving the most emotional and heartbreaking Oscar speech of the recent awards, Thomas Vinterberg's International Feature winner is now in UK cinemas. "Druk" (Danish for "Binge Drinking") is in the Danish language with subtitles: but don't let that put you off.Positives:
Mads Mikkelsen delivers a stunning performance. He really delivers the goods. He was nominated for a BAFTA for the role but missed out on the Oscar nomination. This feels unjust. I would have personally swapped out Steven Yeun for this performance by Mads.Thomas Vinterberg was justly nominated for Best Director at both the BAFTAs and the Oscars. The movie never lacks momentum from beginning to end. I was thoroughly entertained.It's quite unusual to see a 'buddy movie' concerning a group of men that's not a cop film. My wife described it as a '"chick-flick for blokes". I guess you need to go to "The Hangover" films to find an equivalent. (That of course also centres around alcohol. Are we really that shallow?!)Negatives:
Up until a "church scene", I thought the story was well-structured and coherent. But I'm not quite sure what message the finale of the movie was trying to send. Yes, it's fun and full of energy. And Mikkelsen's dancing is both bizarre and entertaining. But given all that's gone before, is it a "what the hell, life is for living and alcohol is part of that" statement? I was unsure.Summary Thoughts on "Another Round": The movie is dedicated to "Ada" - Vinterberg's daughter, who was supposed to be acting in the film but tragically died in a car crash just four days into shooting. (Hence his emotional Oscar acceptance). The fact he managed to finish the movie at all is amazing. But the fact it's so good is a great memorial to her.It's billed as a "comedy drama" but, although there are comic moments, it leans heavily on the "drama". The Scandinavians in general tend to drink as much, if not more, than the British do. So this is a reminder of both the benefits and risks of the evil drink.(For the full graphical review, please check out One Mann's Movies on the web, Facebook or the Tiktok channel onemannsmovies. Thanks.)

Danish/Swedish co-production from director Thomas Vinterberg starring Mads Mikkelsen best known to mainstream filmwatching audiences as characters such as James Bond villain Le Chiffre in Casino Royale (2006) as well as collaborating in a previous Vinterberg film with great success, The Hunt (2012).The premise is slightly exciting based on a factual idea from a Norweigan psychiatrist Finn Skårderud, that humans naturally have a blood-alcohol level lower than what it should be.Four Danish schoolteachers including history teacher Martin (Mikkelsen) test the idea to inject some zest into their moribund mid-life personal and professional lives.Martin in particular describes his circumstances his failing relationship with wife Anika and poor history teaching career that had so much spark and potential a few years before. The students and principal aren't particularly endeared to his teaching performance with end of school exams on the horizon for some.Initially the 'experiment' is positive and slightly comedic in that they find their mojos as such. Slightly drunk but not to excess and within control.However as the film progresses the blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is notched up bit by bit with tragic consequences. Vinterberg neither glamourises or demonizes alcohol culture and the director shows both sides of the coin cleverly using historic figures such as Winston Churchill and Hitler as examples of historic leaders who were either regular drinkers by their own admission and control yet heroes to many (Churchill) and tea totallers yet historic demons to many (Hitler). There is also a little montage of alcohol in modern day political life from Yeltsin and Clinton to Boris Johnson and Angela Merkel.The tragic consequences shown are the usual symptoms of alcoholism and include career difficulties, physical injuries from falls etc. Relationship issues and breakdowns.Excellent performances from the principal cast not only Mikkelsen in the comedic and tragedy scenes.The ending initially comes across as a bit corny for want of a better word but on reflection the celebratory scenes rather than Danish students and their teachers dancing around a harbour as if it is a musical could be a celebration by Martin or as in the title is he just starting the journey into 'Another Round' just as his life is turning a corner?Rightfully received awards recognition including winning Best International Feature Film at the Academy Awards in 2021.

Review By Kamal KA rather interesting concept that is executed brilliantly. It's probably quite a relatable issue aswell, particularly for those who rely on alcohol for some kind of release for their busy day-to-day lives.Mads' character is the one particularly focused on as he is the one who has the most to gain from the experiment, dealing with communication/social issues between his students and his family. So it's also quite a treat to see his character development throughout everything that happens.Overall, a rather enjoyable watch that will leave you feeling satisfied. And if you've ever wondered what it would be like to day drink regularly this movie will certainly make up your mind.

Review title: A celebration of Binge drinking nothing more
Review_body:
My Review- Another Round or "Druk" (translation Drinking or Boozing )
My Rating 4/10The 2021 Best International Feature Academy Award Winning film from Denmark.We got around to watching this film from Denmark and I didn't know what to expect and perhaps I got lost in Translation.I'm not a wowser those who enjoy a Social drink good luck to them but I found this movie very confronting and totally unenjoyable.Denmark has some of the highest rates of teenage drinking in the world; a World Health Organization report released earlier in 2020 found that Danish 15-year-olds consumed alcohol at nearly double the European average. Recent efforts to raise the minimum age for purchasing alcohol to 18 from 16 have met with resistance, in part because older adults recall their own youthful intoxications so fondly so you would think a film about 4 rather stupid men consuming huge amounts of alcohol in an experiment wouldn't serve Denmark or any other Nation well , it's certainly not a comedy like " The Hangover "2008 which I haven't seen out of choice.While the acting is excellent in "Another Round." and I've yet to see the other 4 nominated International Feature films which were "Quo Vadis, Aida?" (Bosnia and Herzegovina), The Man Who Sold His Skin Tunisia, Collective Romania, and Better Days Hong Kong I really disliked "Druk" and the translation is quite accurate it's all about Drinking snd Boozing and it leads nowhere expect and says nothing except to quote a line from the movie from Martin's Mads Mikkelson wife Anika (Maria Bonnevie) "I don't care how much you drink all Danes drink like madmen " and that's all this film is about
four high school teachers who consume alcohol on a daily basis in an "experiment " to see how it affects their social and professional lives.What did they expect would happen ?Of course they go crazy , their students and Principal have an intervention ,their marriages and children are traumatised one dies . (Sorry spoiler but I hope no one sees this film)
The reason being from the opening scenes of crazy teenagers drinking and misbehaving in a train to the last scenes of Mads Mickkelsen showing his acrobatic skills in a joyful salute to out of control alcohol abuse.The actor Mads Mikkelsen ends Thomas Vinterberg's film with a wild delight of a drunken dance. He was a professional dancer and can certainly move well but this movie had absolutely nothing to offer me at all and I can't recommend it at all.

Great acting, felt genuine and realistic. Good story, but I felt like the film drove itself into a corned with the narrative. With this message about alcohol, the concequences felt a little forced and not that fleshed out. But apart from that good movie, that actually made me laught a handfull of times.7/10: yeah.

Review title: An Unique Take, Digging the Deeper Facets of Alcoholism.
Review_body: Leading up to the Academy Awards this season, "Another Round" a Danish production by Thomas Vinterberg; is deemed to be a strong contender for the majority of film fanatics. Yet being brutally honest; I couldn't get behind all these startling praises. Don't get me wrong, I got my own reasons as well!"You must accept yourself as fallible in order to love others and life" - Søren KierkegaardOut of all names in the nomination list for this year's Oscars; this would be my less preferred pick. In no way, I'm asserting my adverse opinion that the film is bad. Matter of fact, It's pretty darn good. But there are certain things that require pressing consideration!Whereas the story proceeds to unveil whatever damage caused by immoderate liquor consumption; it also ratifies the yearlong tradition in Denmark adjacent to the same matter. In all fairness; for an outlander like me, it is clearly hard to comprehend. Anyway, I get the feeling that somewhere in its transitions the underlying value of the key message slowly faded away.Although it sheds light on multiple crucial perspectives such as life, family, friendship; yet it all appears to be incomplete for some odd reason. On the other hand, there are certain sequences volubly brandishing an absolute brilliance and there's no denying its infallible quality of being subtle and evocative; all at once.Needless to say, other than its trivial shortcomings in the narrative; elsewhere, this has been quite a show worth beholding! Mainly apropos of the striking Cinematography; which quite frankly has exceeded all my expectations. And so did the poignant Score in the back.Finally coming down to the heart & soul of this whole endeavor i.e. The Performances. Long story short, the entire cast did an amazing job! Whilst Mads Mikkelsen as Martin got the largest share of screen time over here; Others did all they could with their limited exposure. Must say, I would have loved to see them equally making viable contributions to the same cause.

Review title: One of the most engaging studies of the effects of alcohol on the human body ever put to film
Review_body: "Another Round" (a.k.a. "Druk") is a comedy drama film directed and co-written by Thomas Vinterberg ("The Hunt"). Starring Mads Mikkelsen in the lead role, it is one of the most engaging studies of the effects of alcohol on the human body ever put to film.In Copenhagen, Denmark, high school teachers Martin (Mads Mikkelsen), Nikolaj (Magnus Millang), Tommy (Thomas Bo Larsen), and Peter (Lars Ranthe) are long time friends who each believe that their lives have become uninteresting over the years. At Nikolaj's 40th birthday party, the quartet decide to conduct an experiment where they consume alcohol at work to test a theory that a person with a BAC (Blood Alcohol Content) of 0.05% performs with a heightened level of creativity and confidence. As the days go by, each of the four friends discover that things are improving for them significantly and soon agree to take the experiment further by increasing their BAC limit to higher percentages.In pretty much every country where it's legal, drinking alcohol is widely considered to be a normal part of a fun night out where one is able to let loose every once and a while. Coming from Australia, one of the most well-known countries in the world to focus around drinking culture, I can personally attest to this as I myself have attended my fair share of parties where such an occurrence is the norm among young and old. As is usually the case with something this important, there are bound to be several films focusing around the consumption of alcohol that are meant to show how much the characters can handle before doing something they later regret. "Another Round" not only follows this formula to such a wonderful degree, but it also works brilliantly as a tragic commentary on middle age affecting one's acceptance in society.On the surface, this film may come across as a mere pastiche about group of friends getting drunk simply so they can function better at work. I think such an assessment is unfair because there is far more to this when examined more closely. Alcohol affects every person differently - some develop more confidence in their social abilities while others turn into a depressed wreck. One thing is for certain though, it changes people into someone they normally aren't when sober. This film cleverly uses each of its four main characters to show the various ways of how alcohol is both benefitting and worsening their lives. As a result of this, the film neither glorifies nor condemns its usage, instead depicting it almost as a tool that requires a particular set of skills to master.Each of these four men feel like that they are in a midlife slump with a nostalgic longing for the good old days. Take Martin for example, who is a history teacher whose students don't even respect him anymore due to how bland his teaching methods have become as a result of growing older. One student even stands up and leaves his class out of sheer boredom, not caring one bit if he gets into trouble. When Martin starts drinking before entering the classroom, he transforms into an entirely new person. Before you know it, he is engaging his class in jovial lectures on historical leaders and bringing out the best traits of his students. Like spinach to Popeye the sailor, alcohol eventually serves as a dependable means of acquiring the necessary strength for Martin to accomplish otherwise difficult tasks.But it isn't all good news for him. Eventually, Martin's overdependence on the liquid courage distances him from his family, putting a strain on his marriage. Martin's wife Anika finds it hard to comprehend that the man she married is now more concerned with looking good in front of his students than her. Despite assuring her that he is currently the best person he has ever been, Martin soon realises he has achieved this goal through selfish means. At this point, the film addresses Martin's deeply rooted insecurity - he is fearful that growing old has impeded his chances at success to fit in with the younger generation. These feelings of self-doubt are common among the middle-aged population, so it certainly isn't difficult to believe that many others out there must feel the same way as poor Martin.Director Thomas Vinterberg does a flawless job intertwining each of the four characters' stories with one another, bringing a solid consistency to the overall plot. Although Martin is clearly the main protagonist, his three friends are shown to have just as many interesting traits and quirks worth exploring as well. Due to the nature of their drinking experiment, the four often meet up to see where they are and how things are playing out for them. As previously mentioned, the alcohol affects each of them differently so it's fun to see the results of their lengthy investigation. In doing so, there's a nice balance between genuine drama and tongue-in-cheek comedy that makes a film like this seem so much more sincere than other alcohol-related features of this type.As Martin, Mads Mikkelsen gives one of the best performances of his career. This character could easily have been just another generic man facing a midlife crisis but Mikkelsen brings such a likeable, charming, and often humorous tone to the way he plays him that I eagerly anticipated everything he was about to do next. He never feels like a caricature of a typical drunken dad, instead he's a tragic individual who wants to improve his life as quickly as possible. The three other actors, Magnus Millang, Thomas Bo Larsen, and Lars Ranthe, were also great in their respective roles as Martin's friends. They too have their own obstacles they need to overcome but their differing worldviews prevent this from being a smooth journey.In this day and age where films tend to sensationalise alcohol consumption, it feels like a breath of fresh air to finally watch one that actually provides a more neutral perspective on everything. Though it is true that alcohol has been the cause of many issues in people's lives, it has also led to the creation of several amazing things as well. Renowned author Ernest Hemingway claimed to have written some of his best work while under the influence, but in stark contrast, millions of lives are lost worldwide each year due to excessive drunkenness. The key here is moderation, like the use of an important musical instrument in the composition of a symphony. To quote the immortal words of Homer Simpson: "To alcohol! The cause of - and solution to - all of life's problems!"I rate it a solid 9/10.

Very original movies. Usually movies are outlined about characters who try to get sober this one turns it around - Thomas Vinterberg's newest entry to his filmography is actually about "sober" people who want to get drunk to find a sense in life.... it started as an experiment but has a fundamental impact on the character's lives, emotions and developments.
The film is funny and tragic. Its an interesting mix as I wouldn't call it a light drama with comedic highlights like a typical dramedy, it is rather a tragedy with some funny or lets say soft elements. The screenplay is fantastic and very original. I loved Mads Mikkelsen who really deserves all the praise he can get. His performance works on so many different facettes and it is hard to read him - far from every stereotype possible and that is were the magic of Mikkelsen's performance lies in. On paper it is already an ordinary character but he was able to make it truly human - like your ordinary teacher/ father kind of guy. Thomas Bo Larasen is always good and its no difference here. The outstanding performance of he supporting cast are by Magnus Millang and Marie Bonnevie.
Its really a very down to earth film about normal people and normal fates. Very natural.

Review title: Stuck in the middle with booze
Review_body: You know those comedies where a group of friends all agree to _____? Think Hall Pass or Bad Moms. Well, this movie is kind of like that. Except way less silly. And Danish. The good part of that is you get real characters and relationships...so you actually care. The bad part of that is you have to watch characters you care about make ridiculous horrible choices. Overall, I would absolutely take this movie over its American lowest common denominator equivalent (which will probably star Will Ferrell and be made in 2023)...but I still would have preferred a story that leaned more into drama or comedy instead of getting caught in between.

Review title: A fun and tragic look into drinking culture
Review_body: Thomas Vinterberg made a huge impression on me with his 2012 film, The Hunt. This was one of my most anticipated films of 2020 and it certainly delivered.Another Round follows four friends, who are all teachers, that test out a theory that will make their lives better by maintaining a constant level of alcohol in their blood.With Another Round, Thomas Vinterberg has proved once again how talented of a director he is. This is vastly different from The Hunt. That film was depressing all the way through whereas this film plays out more like a comedy. Here, Vinterberg tackles the drinking culture in Denmark and in general and I loved the way he approached it. The sequence of events stayed believable without going overboard. It sets up the characters well in the beginning as we get an understanding of how mundane their life is in contrast to the scenes that take place after they start drinking. This film could have easily taken the route of showing us all the negative aspects of alcohol but Vinterberg strikes a balance in conveying both sides of the spectrum. He shows us all the fun and happiness that can be had with drinking whilst also bringing to light the problems it can create if it starts to get excessive.Some scenes where the four main characters get extremely drunk are really funny and the actors do an exceptional job. I loved Mads Mikkelsen in The Hunt but this might be my favourite performance from him. There is so much emotional range with his character that he expresses beautifully especially during the ending where he steals the show. It's one of the best performances of 2020. Thomas Bo Larsen, Magnus Millang and Lars Ranthe are also amazing and perform excellently when they're drunk. I loved the camaraderie these four actors had on screen. They all felt believable as friends and their characters which elevated the fun in the drinking scenes and the emotion during the more heartfelt scenes. Maria Bonnevie was also really good as Mikkelsen's wife in the film.Another Round is predictable but at the same time I really enjoyed it despite that. Vinterberg examines the drinking culture beautifully with his terrific direction and the exceptional performances by everyone involved made this one of the best films of 2020.

Tied with 'The Hunt' as one of the finest Danish movies (coincidentially the whole artistic team is the same) and is a shocking surprise to me because 'The Hunt' is a disturbing and haunting tragedy. 'Another Round' is a both funny and heartbreaking drama that ends up being an uplifting celebration of Life. Entertaining, human, greatly written and with perfect performances: one of the best movies of the recent years. The final scene is already iconic. What a movie, what a beautiful movie.

What can one even say about a film like this? Vinterberg absolutely nailed the direction. The film was so well written, the acting was absolutely superb, and the characters were all believable, and so true to life.This is a movie that was made by adults, for adults. Mads Mikkelsen gave another one of his master classes in acting, and the rest of the ensemble cast was wonderful. I just do not know how you can improve on a movie like this. The end was icing on the cake. Mads may be one of the best actors of this generation.

Interesting concept about life, education, alcohol and death. I think actors are great on their roles also the original idea is well executed. But, over everything is Mads Mikelsen what an underrated actor by Hollywood. So, overall a great refreshing movie/concept.

"I could use a higher BAC to get a little more self-confidence."Another Round is Thomas Vinterberg's newest film about four friends, all high school teachers, testing a theory that they will improve their lives by maintaining a constant level of alcohol in their blood. I'm not super familiar with his other films other than knowing they're critically praised. So this was basically my first Vinterberg film. I gotta say I'm really impressed. Another Round is a fun and dramatic film that goes to places you wouldn't expect. Leading the film, Mads Mikkelsen gives us a great performance. I really enjoyed his character and what he's going through. The same for the other three. They're all doing this experiment for some fun but they have issues to deal with already. The constant drinking is only adding up to it. The most intriguing part was seeing what consequences would arise amidst all the fun. The comedy lands well and I chuckled a few times. But the drama behind it all exceeded my expectations. The last act had me itching to see what would come up next.Thomas Vinterberg is a great director. Just by watching this film, I am really interested in his other works. He has a refreshing sort of approach but reminds us of what we have to deal with by having a little fun, even if it's illegal. The beginning didn't quite hook me in. I thought by that I would just feel like it would just be good rather than the raving reviews. After a while, it really starts to pick up and I didn't want to stop. The portrayal of this growing alcoholism is good. They didn't pose it as a good or bad thing. Rather it's a neutral view of what it's like and how it affects people differently. Each of the characters have a different reaction. I'm glad there's variation and not just them getting flat out drunk the whole time. And the way the film concludes is a great ending. I don't want to spoil but it just really works. There's not much to digest and analyze. All that needs to be said is Another Round is a great film and another showcasing the best of 2020.

As many have noted, a fine film about the slide into middle age, loss of youth, hope and dreams,
discovery of the bottle. Very well acted and directed, very watchable despite the discomfort of seeing people fail, with a ray of hope just at the end to give that high we need. How long will the hero's luck last? The film quotes Kierkegaard, a noble quote about the recognition of one's own failures necessary to loving others. It might also have quoted Kafka: there is infinite hope in the universe, but not for us.

Vinterberg and Mikkelsen did it again! It's a totally different story and tone here, but Another Round is as good as The Hunt imo.Another difficult thematic to approach, another bunch of scenes that will make you think about it and a lot of not so politically correct scenes/statements again. Another Round feels fresh, feels real and shows one more time that Vinterbeg and Mikkelsen are not afraid of critics while creating their art.One of the best of the year and another amazing interpretation by Mads Mikkelsen (a shame that 99.9% of the time, the Academy only considers foreign movies for a single category, he deserved to be on the best actor discussion and the movie on the best picture).

An interesting topic, alcohol, which is usually talked about nicely in society. The film has a lot to tell about life and, due to its subject matter, shows both positive and negative effects on alcohol consumption and is well balanced. A film well worth seeing. Especially when you're in a similar phase of life as the protagonists. No alcohol does not solve any problems.

Review title: What life dissatisfaction can cause to some people.
Review_body: Thomas Vinterberg is a director capable of turning the most boring and ordinary subject into a compelling plot. Martin, is a high school teacher that basically lost any kind of motivation. He does not enjoy his job anymore, he cannot communicate with his family and he feels so distant from his wife. One day he decides to do an experiment with his colleagues: drinking a little bit of alcohol during the day, in order to be more energetic. The first part is basically a comedy: a group of friends finding purpose in life again. There are many funny scenes that made me laugh. Then, the light-hearted tone becomes darker, things get out of hand and in the second part, the film depicts the dramatic consequences of their choices.I think that the director does a really good job exploring which may be some of the causes for alcohol addiction, how this can influence your everyday life and people around you. The script really deepens characters and their friendship; I felt really attached to them. I think that there was not one single scene wasted, everything fit just perfectly. The cast is phenomenal and it is composed by pretty big names of Danish cinema: Mads Mikkelsen and Thomas Larsen are two of the most famous actors in the industry, but they did not shadow Magnus Millang and Lars Ranthe, who are as good. Every single actor bringed something to the table, and contributed to tell an emotional story. The very last scene with the song performed by Scarlet Pleasure is one of the most beautiful things that I have watched this year.I absolutely enjoyed "Another Round". This movie represents the return of the roots for Mikkelsen, in every sense. I am genuinely happy that after the success obtained through Hollywood blockbusters, he came back to his motherland, promoting, in a way, Danish cinema.

The game of life is more art then science. Which is an idea the film links wonderfully to alcholism. One day you're on top of the world. Teaching better then ever and finally reconnecting with family. Then you wind up bloodied on your neighbors doorstep with little idea how you got there or why you're there. Much like Vinterbergs 2012 feature The Hunt, Another Round stars Mads Mikkelsen. Unlike that movie, he isn't at the heart of a town wide witch hunt for crimes he didn't commit. Instead, Mads is an average history teacher living an average life.That is, until his life turns on a dime. He is a depressed, vaccant shell of a man. Unable to connect with his family and even further distant from his students, Mads seems to be drifting lazily through life. After a short 10 minutes, he and his friends decide it's time to change their boring lives. They begin trying to maintain a consistent, albeit low, blood alcohol level in an attempt to spice things up. Suddenly life is better. Mads is outgoing, energetic, and has no trouble with people.You can probably imagine, this falls apart rather quickly. As is such with alcohol, the more you rely on it, the more you need it to function. A hobby turns to a habit, then a habit into an addiction which spirals out of control. Such is life. The moment you let your guard down it punches you in the gut just to see of you're paying attention. Another Round perfectly captures this idea.However, I'm not to high on this. I think it does a good job saying what it desires and is genuinely quite entertaining. It bounces off the walls with energy while oozing a carefree attitude that was infectious. The problem is, it's pretty on the nose. There's large exposition sections that relay information to the audience in less then subtle ways. These characters are monitoring themselves through an "essay" on the effects they feel over time. Which gives the film room to explain itself. The problem with this is that it goes nowhere. As do many little things here and there.It seems each character is given a distict role to play in the film and it rarely pivots from those ideas. Making this incredibly predictable from the ground up. If you have a thought of where this is going based on the premise, you're probably right. Which is unfortunate because the payoff of the film feels largely unrewarding. A stark difference between The Hunt's absolutely traumatizing 3rd act.I'd still say check this out though. If you have twelve bucks and two hours to sit down at home, pull the trigger on this. It's quite entertaining, delivers a solid message, and props up some pretty great performances. Unfortunately, If you're looking for something to knock you flat with a powerful message or a satisfactory conclusion this doesn't have it. It builds to the exact place you might think and hits the nail on the head even though the nail is already embedded into it's place.

I only watched this because the ratings were so high. I didn't know it's not in English & luckily I don't have an issue reading subtitles. This movie is exactly what it says, nothing more. About 4 high school teachers who decide to keep their blood alcohol level at 0.5 by steadily drinking all day until 8pm. I was very disappointed. This is one of those movies that when it ends you're like that's it? There's no point, no moral, nothing to write home about. I will never watch this again nor can I recommend it. One thing I would like to comment on is that I was blown away that the TEACHERS told a couple of their students who were struggling with their grades to drink alcohol before their finals. This is High School. The teachers handed them hard liquor they kept on them at school & told them to belt back a few big swigs off it because it would help them do better on their finals & not to worry they wouldn't tell anyone. What kind of example does this set? Is that really good advice? Is that truly a good habit to get into? Relying on alcohol to solve the issues they'll run into throughout the rest of their life? I don't think so.

Review title: A film about the positive and negative sides of the use of alcohol.
Review_body: Druk is a new comedy drama directed and written in part by Thomas Vinterberg, the director of The Hunt.In the film, Martin (Mads Mikkelsen) and three other colleagues decide to test the theory that a modest amount of alcohol in the blood can expand your mind during everyday life. This way you can reduce problems and think more creatively. The four high school teachers know how to teach in an inventive and more relaxed way. As the four drink more and more often, they gradually learn that there is also a negative side to drinking alcohol. They have to determine how far they are willing to go for their experiment, before things get too out of hand.Because the Danish director comes from the country that last year had one of the highest percentages of alcohol use among teenagers in the world, he tries to show with this film what the consequences of alcohol can be. Despite the fact that they try to bring out the consequences of alcohol with this film, they show in a well-balanced way what both the positive and negative sides of the use of alcohol can be. In this way, as a viewer, you get the chance to fill in how you think about alcohol until the end of the film without feeling bad about it.The four leading roles of the film not only come across as colleagues but also as good friends of each other. They continue to support each other during their experiment, but also when one of the four has a personal life. Unfortunately, all four are not presented with the same amount of personal information, so as a viewer you care a bit more about one than the other. All four also manage to convey in a believable way that their characters are experimenting with alcohol without doing it in an exaggerated way.

Review title: My own 0.05% experiment is still in progress !!
Review_body:
My interest in Druk grew more only after the movie won an academy award for the best international feature. The movie has a pretty simple storyline of four middle aged friends, who happen to work at the same place,
decide to carry out an interesting experiment with alcohol, which requires them to drink during work hours.As the narrative progresses, "Druk"draws you in with its complexities. Layers of sentiments and human behavior begin to peel away as the four men lose their inhibitions and bringing forth some very raw emotions. Director Thomas Vinterberg gives us a film about living life and he conveys it in equal measures of subtlety, sadness and exhilaration.Cinematography is a mixed bag throughout the movie, it oscillates between some great close ups in the dark to some over-lit bright shots facing the window panes. Screenplay is simple and straightforward, but a bit boring in the middle to support a 117 minute runtime but it pretty much makes it better towards the end. Editing is very raw and bland for my liking but does the job. Production design, costumes and makeup were decent. Music has some good and some bad bits and may not cater to everyone's taste. On the acting front Mads Mikkelson, as the gloomy, listless Martin who goes through many shades of transformation, is simply brilliant. Thomas Bo Larsen, Lars Ranthe and Magnus Millang also pull in good performances.Overall, Director Thomas Vinterberg gets most of the things right in this rather slightly dull affair, which promises a lot in the beginning but goes flat midway. The movie targeted at a 40+ age groups and may not impact to people younger than the mid thirties as much. But As the film draws to its dying moments, In a burst of infectious, joyous energy exuded by Mikkelson in a dance sequence which almost feels exuberant, one realizes that there are no sweeping judgements or any real closure being served here. 6.9 stars out of 10 for running an interesting experiment and celebrating friendship.

Review title: Don't watch if you're already over 0.05% blood alcohol
Review_body: Just watched another round for the second time. Another Another round if you like. It was so much better than the first watch. My theory is that my blood alcohol level was above the optimum 0.05% when I first watched it and thus I wasn't at my optimum self. This time I opened a beer as I first pressed play and topped up accordingly to reach around 0.05% from 30 minutes in to the end. Result? Utterly brillant. Thought provoking. A little sad. But ultimately joyous and made me cry at the end. Moral of the story? Don't have 3 pints before a film (only during)....

Another one of my favourite 2020 films. Again proving that it was a great year for film. Vinterberg integrates depressing subject matter with comedy perfectly, I haven't laughed so much in a long time.Each of the four main actors performances are great, they act drunk incredibly and give nuanced performances. Subtle emotes and raw emotion. Mads Mikkelsen stands out as expected, his character is also the most well defined.Comments on drinking culture, mental illness and the psychology surrounding addiction. I'm really interested in this kind of thing so I'm glad it was incorporated.It's well made and well shot. Ellipses are used frequently and effectively. I liked the music, I wasn't too big on the track 'what a life' at first but I've come around to it since, it's not great music but it's groovy enough to get my toes tapping and most importantly it felt liberating. I love Franz Schubert so hearing 'fantasia in F minor' was awesome, luckily it was used well. Such a beautiful piece.

Review title: Impossible not to crave a drink while watching
Review_body: Within thirty minutes of starting "Another Round," I found myself cracking open a bottle of bourbon and pouring myself a glass. I didn't get nearly as drunk as the characters who inhabit this world, and luckily, I didn't need to in order to enjoy this movie."Another Round" is an excellent drama and character study, following the lives of four high school teachers who decide to see if maintaining a constant level of alcohol in their blood from morning to 8 p.m. will improve their lives, both personally and professionally. And if you think that premise is the start to a whimsical, lighthearted adventure, you'd be half right. From celebratory binges with friends to late night tears over beers, "Another Round" demonstrates people's relationship with alcohol, in all of its beauty and destruction.Mads Mikkelsen was pitch-perfect as a professor who is unsatisfied with his life, seeking solace in the bottle. Displaying a vulnerability and quiet desperation, it is fun to watch his transformation to a confident teacher, husband, and friend once he partakes in his pick of poison. Mads is always great in dramatic roles, and it's no different here. There is one incredibly intense scene where he confronts his wife over something while they are eating dinner which does a fantastic job of showing Mads desperately trying to hold on and have some semblance of control over his personal life. Is alcohol his savior, imprisoner, or both?Thomas Vinterberg does great work in directing little character moments, showing how different each person's relationship with alcohol is. From a student potentially having a shot or two to relieve anxiety during class to professors who partake to improve their teaching abilities, the movie is ever fascinating, never portraying alcohol as good or bad - it simply exists, and it's up to each individual person how they choose to use it. The most interesting part of the movie for me was seeing how each character's life begins to subtlety improve as their drinking increases - at least at first. They become more confident professors, breathing new life into their classes and enriching their students' educational experiences. But, the party must end at some point, and "Another Round" also shows the tragic effects of alcohol abuse as well."Another Round" is an excellent drama that will leave you thinking well after the credits roll. You might relate to the characters and their plight, or you might find them detestable drunks. Regardless, you're sure to have at least a moderately good time with this movie, and if you don't, the performances and drama will surely be enough to hold your interest.

"Another Round" (a.k.a. "Druk") has a fascinating premise, but a messy, stumbling plot that never quite allows for a good film. Four teachers explore the idea that keeping their blood alcohol levels around 0.5 might make their banal lives and dull classrooms a little more exciting... not only for them, but the people around them. Perhaps director, Thomas Vinterberg, should have had a few more shots before filming.... or a few less.

This was...cheerful? And I liked that?Yeah, yeah I did. This must be the most optimistic film about alcoholism I've ever seen, because it's honest about it. It showcases the soaring highs just as much, and just as effectively as the crushing lows, and although it's not a position I've ever been in, it is one I could potentially have been.I remember when I first came to university and tried alcohol in a social setting, and it was like I'd suddenly unlocked a cheat code. I could talk to girls, I could say all that stupid stuff that I thought would make people laugh but never had the confidence to say before, and most of all, I felt happy.It's not like I wasn't before, but I wasn't exactly the most outgoing person, and that was something I badly wanted to be by the time I went to university. Knowing that, you can probably see how I could have all too easily gotten out of hand like the characters in this film do, but thankfully I managed to control myself just before I started drinking alone.I'm sure when parties and clubs can happen again, I'll be getting royally drunk, but I'm glad that I know my limits and when the appropriate times to drink are.All this stupid storytiming is to say that this film is relatable as hell, because man does it nail that feeling of not having a care in the world when you're just that perfect amount of drunk, and it probably nails how easy it is to slip into addiction as well.I'll say that the ending may have been a bit too cheerful considering what happens in the scene prior, and that some more interesting shot composition certainly wouldn't have hurt, but the performances are all brilliant, the direction from Thomas Vinterberg is amazing, the characters are likable, and for how much of a tonal disaster this easily could have been, it pulls it off so well.So if anything I said just now resonates with you, please watch this, cause sometimes, being honest doesn't mean you have to be miserable about it.

This movie just might be the perfect example of how life of an ordinary person who drinks occasionally looks like. Starts out boring as their day-to-day life it speeds up when alcohol becomes their frequent companion day in day out up to the point of no return mark and that's usually when someone gets hurt or when it gets ugly (or both). Alcohol pretends to be your friend to make you feel good and confident, it loosens you up and shows your inner fears, thoughts, your hidden demons and not everyone is strong enough to cope with being on the loose all the time. In general Another round speaks loudly of all those things and would be relevant for everyone who knows drinking problems not by hearsay (which is like half of earth's population), to all of the others it would be just another movie with its moral shouting loudly since the beginning and its general idea spoiled in its poster already. That's why I intentionally named this review after D.W. Griffith's infamous 1909 short feature because of how similar they both are in concept. Overall this is a good movie with some nice soundtrack, fine dramatic performances (although a bit too strained for me), some proper thoughts to think about and a smooth aftertaste.

Review title: (2020 list except) Vinterberg skillfully lampoons drinking culture
Review_body: Another Round, or Druk in Danish, is a depressing-yet-comical exploration of the modern religion that is alcohol consumption.Being a veteran of the Dogme 95 movement, writer-director Thomas Vinterberg skillfully makes the film feel natural and, in accordance with the manifesto, almost never artificial (the movie looks to be shot in real locations with mostly natural lighting). Similarly convincing are Mads Mikkelsen and his co-stars, continually making me forget that these are actors and that there is a screen between us. Mikkelsen is emotionally convincing and has an absolutely glorious dance number near the end of the movie.As a Scandinavian, I can verify that it accurately depicts the drinking culture we have here. There have been complaints that the portrayal seems a bit exaggerated for the sake of a point, but I assure you; our high school graduates absolutely ride around on loud party trucks with champagne close at hand.

Short summaryVinterberg (so far from his previous film The Hunt) makes a portrait of the midlife crisis of four friends. His idea of a Faustian pact that they make between themselves and with alcohol to overcome it is interesting as I propose and it is beautifully musicalized, very well directed and superbly acted. But the film sadly slides down the slope of the obvious, the conservative message regarding its winners and losers and, worse, demagoguery. It is no accident that he won an Oscar.ReviewFour friends, secondary school teachers in the same school, decide to do an experiment, following the advice of a Norwegian psychiatrist: to start the systematic consumption of alcohol in order to be able to deal with the discomfort caused by their work and family life.Mads Mikkelsen plays a history teacher fed up with teaching, distracted in the classroom and cut off from his wife. His friends are teachers of physical education, music and psychology and with few brushstrokes, we find out about their respective discomforts. One of them proposes to follow the indications of Finn Skarderud, a Norwegian psychiatrist, who supposedly recommends a certain level of alcohol in the blood to improve the relationship with an environment that produces discomfort. In this way, the four friends make a pact and begin to drink alcohol to ensure that daily blood alcohol level.The film shows us the effects that are obtained, in this experiment sustained as a group, but with individual consequences. It is not by chance that the film begins with a ritual in which the students, at the end of high school, carry out a race where it is necessary to drink an enormous amount of alcohol as a requirement to win it. The pact of the four friends has an undeniable adolescent look and needs this kind of scientific legitimation for the acquisition of a habit that ends up challenging that premise. Even an example that Mikkelsen uses in a class incurs a fallacious investment that corresponds to the one that he proposes in the experiment. On the other hand, from the start, they consider the consumption of alcohol as an instrument and not as enjoyment in itself. All this in a society with a satiety fed by its basic needs satisfied and with a very high average intake of alcohol.Another round is of those films in which one wonders, averaging the story and with growing discomfort, what its director is proposing to tell us, what is the message. Because all fiction contains a message, or at least raises questions. And I continue with this bewilderment once I finished watching it and now, despite all the considerations I made in the previous paragraph. Will it be so obvious that you have to drink in moderation or that drinking can never be a method of improvement? And this does not speak well of the film.This kind of portrait that Vinterberg makes (so far from his film The Hunt) of the midlife crisis of four friends and the idea of a Faustian pact that they make between themselves and with alcohol to overcome it is interesting, although it is beautifully set to music. , very well directed and superbly acted, it unfortunately slides down the slope of the obvious, the conservative message regarding its winners and losers and, what is worse, demagoguery. It is no coincidence that it has won an Oscar.

Review title: A truly different and fascinating concept
Review_body: It's a pretty interesting movie, with an interesting concept (that I truly considered could be valid before googling it after finishing the movie lol), and it's overall beautifully shot, with great acting, cinematography and soundtrack.The camera is mainly hand held I would assume, so it gives you a fairly fluid effect throughout, and mainly on the drunk scenes I think it positively affects the experience of the movie itself overall.Mads Mikkelsen is just a phenomenal actor, and it shows here every freaking scene, he's great, all the four protagonists of sorts are really good in here, as is Maria Bonnevie as Martin's wife too. So, the cast is pretty solid overall.The story tho, I'm a bit conflicted, for most of it I loved the story, and I thought it had gotten the message it was trying to pass, however, after the movie is over, I don't really know.Cause, well, they drink, it sort of helps mainly Martin at first, but, of course he exceeds himself and losses it, as do his friends, they stop, but Tommy isn't able to, and that is clearly what kills him, Martin gets a text from his wife, saying she misses him too, implying Martin has a chance to get his family back... but then they are all drinking and partying like crazy again, in what I assume is still during the day of Tommy's funeral, so... what is the message here? Like, we see the characters go through hell cause of their bad choices, then we root for them, we want them to get better, their friend just died, and here they are getting wasted again? I just find it hard to understand the characters motivation at the end, and it feels a bit like wasted time when at the end of the story, you feel like the characters learned nothing.I had an amicable debate with a friend about the movie afterwards, and well, he strongly defended the story, and the finale for the most part, saying it was actually supposed to be a critic on Danish culture, and the fact that they drink like crazy. And well, fine, ok, I get that, I can see it, and I respect it and like most of the stuff they putted in here as a clear critic. However, still, imo what Martin does at the end, in a lot of ways sorts of denies most of the stuff we thought he had learned throughout the story. And as I said, it feels tough to relate to a character we feel should have learned a lot from the experience he just had, but apparently didn't.Still, I think the movie has a great cinematography, it's pretty well directed and has great performances all throughout, it's definitely worth watching, but the end sort of ruined what I thought would be one of my favorite movies of 2020.

Four teachers decide to consume alcohol daily, in a controlled way, to put a theory to the test.To begin with, Another Round is not a film that celebrates alcoholism or the culture of excess. In some ways I consider this film to be one of the best since a long long time, because of the way it keeps the storyline attractive and exciting from start to finish.At its core, Another Round is an internal battle, ranging from existential doubts to nirvana, through issues such as depression, marital problems and the worst about human behavior.It's provocative, daring, corrosive and delightfully fun. It's a coming-of-age in reverse, a Benjamin Button, if you can say that.Mads Mikkelsen is superb, an actor who has shown his talent over the years, however, I do not feel that he has surpassed the role that for me is his best: The Hunt, also by Thomas Vinterberg.

Review title: Mikkelsen shines in this cathartic tragicomedy!
Review_body: The nailed-on favourite and today, the winner of the Best Foreign Film Oscar-Another Round is a transcendental journey of an introverted school teacher going through a midlife crisis.He joins three other middle-aged friends to embark on a depraved social experiment to see if daily alcohol intake can curb their inhibitions and make them more sociable and confident.While the downsides of alcoholism is well covered, I think the core message that Director Vinterbeg wanted to convey is that one should get high on life to get that extra spring in your step every day.Mads Mikkelsen's gripping performance as the fidgety, timid teacher is a big stretch from the suave Bond Villain characters we are used to from him. But is in this space that he excels, and I can't comprehend how he did not get a Best Actor nomination for this.Another Round is a delightful tragicomedy. Cathartic stuff.

Bored? Stuck? Middle-aged? Why not try the greatest elixir guaranteed to open up the mind, free up the tongue, and see the world in a cheerier light? Well you sir, and you madam are in luck, for this anti-inhibitor miracle which comes in a dazzling array of colours and tastes, is readily available and could well be right under your very noses. That's right, booze!Four cranky high school teachers, grinding the second gear of life with no foreseeable excitement ahead, decide to liven up their days with the magic of alcohol under a seemingly scientific experiment excuse.The theorem:
the human body's alcohol level is a tad low, and requires some topping up to run at optimum efficiency.The experiment:
the subjects drink steadily throughout the working day in an anti-sobriety test, and carefully monitor the results in a very clinical manner, using a computer!The result:
well, that would be telling, but chances are most astute viewers will connect the plot dots without much effort.The conclusion:
what sounds like a half-baked script for a slapdash comedy aimed at the immature set, turns out to be quite the serious and thought-provoking film. Also: Mads Mikkelsen stars, which is always welcome.Alcohol over indulgence is a major issue in dark Denmark, and as such this film will pierce many a Scandinavian home with a personal arrow. For those abroad "Another Round" will be less of a cautionary tale, and more of a buddy-buddy-buddy-buddy story of supposedly grown men wrestling with their maturity and various mid-life crises. It is not all about the drink, but why they drink. Using harried, jaded, aging teachers in charge of jubilant youth about to kickstart their glorious lives, is an intoxicating stroke of genius.Did I mention that Mads Mikkelson stars?
Excellent.hipCRANK

Review title: Mad Mikkelsen runs the wild show!
Review_body: Once upon a time, a Norwegian psychiatrist posed a theory that people are born with the blood alcohol content 0.05% too low. Four 40 year old highschool teachers decide to test that theory - in the name of science- by maintaining a state of perpetual tipsiness while they are working and going about their lives. Needless to say, it turned out into one hell of a movie!The experiment was a smashing success. Our heroes enjoy every minute of this study by stashing bottles everywhere, finally connecting with their students and galavanting around the town without a care in the world. The film itself becomes brighter and more colorful as we watch Mads and his palls get into all sorts of situations. Before watching, I knew that a film about alcohol consumption is meant to have a number of moral lessons and before long, those lessons are presented in a most heartbreaking way.Thomas Vinterberg and Mads Mikkelsen deliver yet another thought provoking and moving film that will stay with me for a long time. Each character hopes that the experiment will help with their particular life problem and while it does help to an extent, the price ends up being too high. The way it progresses from innocent joy and warmth to somber reality is reflected in both the cinematography and terrific acting.Whether you consume alcohol or not, this is a film that you need to watch. Another Round masterfully manages to have an absolute blast while teaching an important lesson without ever being "in your face" about it's messages. Alcohol is a big part of society regardless of country, social strata or age and the film shows that it is personal responsibility to determine how much of it is truly enough. What deserves a special mention is how this story is wrapped up in one of most enjoyable endings of 2020.movies.shmovies on Instagram for more great movies

Review title: A feel good film that hits hard when it needs to
Review_body:
POSITIVES:1) The four leads are all incredible. Mads obviously carries the film as the lead, Martin, but the other actors were really great too
2) The emotional moments of the film really worked for me, for example I really cared about how Martin and Anika's relationship was going to turn out
3) I was surprised by how much the film actually stuck to the theme of the drinking being a psychological experiment, there are frequent call backs to the leads writing their research down
4) Seeing Martin finally dance at the end was euphoric; the whole film people are trying to get him to dance and he says no, but then at the end he finally lets loose and I found it so fantastic
5) The film is very heartfelt in a very realistic way, the relationship with Tommy and Specs was so down to earth which made it hit homeNEGATIVES:1) I definitely felt the film was too long, there was about 20 minutes that felt like they were bagging the run time
2) The switching of the gears with the experiment felt quite rushed to me. It really doesn't take long for the four of them to agree to do the experiment, then once they do it really doesn't take long for the four of them to agree to up the stakes multiple times
3) There was a couple of times where it was difficult to tell how much time had passed between one scene and the next, sometimes it felt like long periods of time had passed but it was difficult to tell; the film could've done a better job at illustrating when long periods of time had passed between scenes.

Review title: Drinking like only the Danish can
Review_body: Dark, joyful, challenging and wondrously complex, this is a character study of the double-edged sword that alcohol can be in the lives of those seeking revival, release or escape or in the case of four Danish schoolteachers, coping with midlife crisis and a desire to feel free again. These colleagues and friends initially view the concept as a curiosity, but as soon as one of them (Mads Mikkelsen in an explosive performance) actually experiments with the idea, his enthusiasm becomes infectious. From that point on, their curiosity evolves into an obsession and their lives and those around them are affected accordingly.I dare say this film conveys its complicated message and portrayal of human weakness with such realism that it's almost like a documentary. It's highly unlikely that an American film on the same subject would have been this powerful or this real. Do you still smell the alcohol?This is hardly a brand new topic for a film to cover, but this one does it so well, that it makes the whole subject matter seem devastatingly fresh and incredibly real. The best compliment that I can pay is that the characters are true to life in their behavior, in their gradual collapse of discipline and in the impact they have on their families and students. You cannot look away. You can only wonder how it will all end. The film subtly shifts between anguish and exuberance with stunning skill. This is first-rate filmmaking. Highly recommended whether this is your drink or not.

The message of this movie may be depressing but it is very accurate.The film is different by exposing the subject of the consequences of alcohol consumption, it manages to give its message very clearly, not only exposes what can happen to you but also how it affects your family and all the people around you. It is a harsh criticism of the normalized excess consumption of alcohol and how it affects society, not only in adults but also in young people, it also refers to the fact that alcohol is only an escape from reality and who does not want to accept reality will do everything possible to avoid it without realizing it. It is very well acted, the script is wonderful, and it even makes you reflect on why we like to consume alcohol so often. It is definitely worth a look, it has a very well deserved Oscar.

I will say this, let me say this, what I'm going to say is, on that one now, Mads Mikkelsen is most certainly a star. He can dance, he can act like Hannibal Lecter, he can bleed out of his eyes, and he can even be in video games.Druk is not quite the warning of alcohol abuse and dependency that Days of Wine and Roses was. It meanders through various tones and moods, begging the question: "What is Danish for 'melodramedy'?" Also, there must be a word in Danish for schadenfreude. Too much fun can be swell, but of course the high-school teachers will take their buzz-worthy experiment of maintaining 0.05% BAC too far, going from quarter-cocked to half-cocked and ultimately totally corked.The movie only suffers from an inability to suspend disbelief. It is hard to believe four teachers would engage seriously in such an experiment, risking their jobs and family lives. There is no finger-wagging or tsk-tsking. We must decide for ourselves whether we should drink more or less, resulting in a simple moral ambiguity instead of some stern moral lesson.Drinking booze can be fun, sometimes it can be dangerous, sometimes it creates a feedback loop of anxiety and depression. Is it possible to understand joy without sadness? Is it possible to be a responsible drinker, or should everything be done in moderation, including moderation?

Thomas Vinterberg manages without hesitating to interest with a singular story, with equally singular subjects and mindsets. Simple shots, complex in their intents, in their conception, but effective in rendering. Film that understands and explains how the concepts of "resilience" and "party" are allegorically hidden in many other facets of life, with much deeper meanings, where no one knows what lies behind a face; moreover there is always to be taken into account the inner "beast" that wants to escape from a monotonous world, on a metronome, too tight and when it comes out it seems that the world rejects the different, which is not different at all. Massive-caliber actors, imposing, poignant and funny at the same time, with a spectacular Mads Mikkelsen who reconfirms his statuesque actoriality.

In line with the premise of the film - that humans are born with not enough alcohol in their bloodstream - I am actually writing this review while under the influence of alcohol. Lucky me :-)Mads Mikkelsen and his co-stars give a realistic and heartfelt performance as friends who decide to experiment with alcohol as a way of enhancing their teaching methods at the school they all work at.The pacing is good and the acting top notch. Review title: A deep analysis of alcohol drinking
Review_body: TIFF 2020 09Another RoundFour close friends who are all high school teachers decide to maintain a specific blood rate of alcohol in their bodies in order to become happier, function better at work and social life, and get along better with their lives. What happens in this process of controlled alcoholism testing and its results consist the main storyline of Another Round, a collaboration of Mads Mikkelsen and Thomas Vinterberg.Each one of these four are explored individually for us to become acquainted with them and get to know their lives, their responsibilities and their problem whether at work or at home. But the film really shines in the scenes that all four are together, drinking, talking about their drinking thesis, laughing and sometimes, crying. This film is about alcohol consumption as much as midlife crisis, isolation, everyday repetition, loneliness, hopelessness and anhedonia. It's a film that resonates with all of us, it's about everyone in this world who struggles with serious problems in one's life and sees the solution in drinking regularly.

Thomas Vinterberg's Druk is about alcoholism; its attractiveness and destructiveness. Four middle aged friends who all work together; three of them teachers, and one a coach, decide to experiment with alcohol in their professional life as a means of increasing productivity in what they all perceive to be a boring life in some way or another. And from this point on, each decision made in this movie plays out exactly as you would imagine... but then that's what it is about. To me, the sober viewer, it is as clear as day, the implications and the effects the next round is bound to have... but not to the men who are already involved. It's almost as if a sense of safety and precaution is what you sacrifice first, and it was shown with much excellence on screen.Major credit to lead actor Mads Mikkelsen who channeled life through the screen. His evolving personality in this movie was portrayed so convincingly with passion and flow, and for that, he deserves every bit of praise. To anyone reading this, do check it out too when you have the chance. You won't regret it.

Review_body:
Photography, editing, scene design and the overall direction aren't good. Half an hour should have been cut.
The actors do their jobs but the characters/storylines aren't convincing: the screenplay feels just ok (I don't speak Danish so I can judge only based on the unofficial subtitles).
The subject-story deserves instead my praise: a remake might be a good idea.The initial Kierkegaard's quote should set the standpoint for the viewer (something which many revieweres here don't seem to have gotten).
The authentic ways of life all of us lost by becoming adults can be brought back by drinking alcohol. But is this an acceptable solution to deal with socio-economic and juridical pressures, cultural taboos, personal and interpersonal issues?
What do we really accomplish by drinking? The film's answer - as per my interpretation - is quite good: general, complex, non-preachy, open-ended and uncompromisingly tragic.

The list of talents from Mads just keeps on going.2. The Danes are apparently heavy into their drinking culture, and there is no age limit for drinking alcohol (age 16 to purchase but anyone can drink at any time), and drinking in public is encouraged.3. "Another Round" features a lot of laughing, celebratory scenes but those scenes don't feel cheerful to the audience. The movie is good at making the viewer feel uneasy and aware that there is an undercurrent of looming tragedy disguised by all the partying and camaraderie.4. Review title: A little alcohol makes you smarter, but it is addictive
Review_body:
This film has got the Oscar for best International film, and therefore should be on your must see list
A Norwegian philosopher Skarderud has said that
" Human beings are born with alcohol level that is 0.05% too low". Does it mean can they can drink up to make up this deficiency and get smarter ? (Incidently this view has been contested)
So celebrated director Thomas Vinterberg makes an engaging movie on this subject.Four middle aged high school teachers of Sweden find their job mundane and boring. They decide to drink alcohol in moderation as an experiment to bring zing in their lives not realizing the consequences in store. They also prepare a day to day report on the effects of their drinking.Director has created a film which is entertaining and throws up some issues like midlife crisis, excessive drinking, school kids drinking etc against the backdrop of a Denmark school. The teachers led by Martin ( Mads Mikkelson) do find increased energy in their work and the happy students also experience this change in their teachers. However alcohol is addictive as they soon find out and their drunken demeanor puts their professional and private life in a downward spiral. Martin's marriage is in jeopardy and nearing divorce. All four manage to save their sanity and give up the experiment. The last scene with Mads dancing and enjoying with his colleagues and school kids is a highlight.An enjoyable film which is funny and touching in many places.

The Good: I love this movie. I fully expected another moralizing tale about the evils of alcohol. Instead, we get a more realistic take: alcohol isn't going anywhere and maybe it really shouldn't. In our age of peak isolation and loneliness, it's sort refreshing to see a film that celebrates alcohol's ability to loosen people up, the warmth you have from drinking with a group of friends and the satisfaction of a well made drink. It's also an exploration of Danish drinking culture and how - like it or not - drinking is essential to Danish life. Vinterberg doesn't proclaim this as good or bad, but certainly spends a lot of time showing us how a world without alcohol is frankly, a lesser one. This movie is about so much: friendship, marriage, growing up, personal development, the meaning of life.It almost goes without saying, but the performances are amazing here; Mikelsen, as usual, stands out. But everyone has such fantastic screen presence, especially when inebriated. The attention to detail with the drinking scenes makes you wanna grab a cold one as soon as possible.The Bad: nothing really, to be honest. I'd be nitpicking.The Ugly: that feeling when you wake up and you still feel drunk from the night before and you know no amount of sleeping will help you. Sucks, man.

It is solid, and together with the Riders of Justice, Zentropa has created a solid 2020 for themselves.

Review title: One of the best of 2020, a great, memorable and meaningful experience!
Review_body: Plot:Four friends, all high school teachers, test a theory that they will improve their lives by maintaining a constant level of alcohol in their blood.Analysis:2020 was a really underwhealming year for cinema, big productions and highly anticipated movies were postponed and fewer films were released due to the pandemic. Despite that, there were some memorable ones that have to be mentioned and Another Round was one of the best without a doubt. With a realtable story that points out the problems of alcoholism, some great performances, the amazing duo of actor Mads Mikkelsen and director Thomas Vinterberg who made the amazing Jagten 8 year ago and some great artistic choices, this was a well-made accessible film that everyone can enjoy and relate to.Starting with the great acting, Mads Mikkelsen is obviously the star in this movie, a talented man that gave this role the appropriate emotion and passion, Martin is the main focus of this movie, his journey is pretty relatable, it includes major problems of modern life and that's were Mads Mikkelsen shines, he brings out the inner pain and conflict perfectly and visualizes the character's mindset so the viewer can subconsciously be totally invested. He is a great and a very talented actor who gets better and better by staying true to his artistic vision. The whole cast was pretty good too, Thomas Bo Larsen, Magnus Millang, Lars Ranthe, everyone was really succesful on his role and they were all a major factor of this film's success.The story was also amazing, it doesn't hold back and stays true to the realism it needed to have, some scenes are casual and others are totally brutal, leaving you with the bittersweet taste that real life has. It's a great representation of a problem that most people will exaggerate or ignore, but here it's being treated with great respect, it's perfectly realistic and the creator manages to bring out the right message without chessy dialogue, or cringey pseudo-emotional scenes. Another Round is a light drama that has the appropriate effect to the viewer, keeping the balance between sadness and happiness for a rare, impactful and realistic result.Thomas Vinterberg proved many times that he is a very talented and innovative creator that doesn't compromize when it comes to storytelling and direction. He doesn't follow the classic pattern of drama movies, he uses it to reinvent the genre and bring out the balance he needs with smooth and satisfying transition between pain and redemption, love and hate, wisdom and foolishness, he knows how to create interesting characters and the result is memorable and beloved films that stand out and express his artistic vision to an audience who's thirsty for something new.Alcoholism is a major problem, a hidden enemy, something that can happen to anyone. Many people tend to drink more and more to relax and forget their issues. The beautiful dizziness where anxiety doesn't exist is an addictive situation and this movie presents this whole subject as perfectly as it could and as realistic as it is, not a visible situation that anyone can notice, but a discreet problem that grows bigger and bigger.Conclusion:These films are what cinema was made for, Another Round entertains and informs the viewer at the same time, it's a must-watch piece of art, not too complicated for people to experience, easily accessible and meaningful. Movies like this one deserve everyone's attention for their artistic value with no hint of pretentiousness.Rating: 9/10

Review title: Liked it but did not love it.
Review_body: It is a good film that deserves its accolades. The direction is competent and the movie is constructed around an interesting and creative premise: that the human body is made to tolerate a higher level of alcohol than naturally present.Yet the movie kinda falls short in the third act. It takes you to high places and then to really low points, but then it does not know how to resolve it. The plot lays out a number of thread and ideas, but it does not conclude them satisfyingly. It botches the resolution or abandons most of them to end in a soft happy end that is somewhat disappointing. When you learn that it is based on a short the director made years ago, it makes sense. It does feel like they streched a neat tidy idea without an end in sight. You could shave a half hour of the movie and not lose anything.The first half is great though. From the beginning, you discover that it is a movie about Martin's middle-life crisis disguised as a social drama on the effects of alcohol. It is cleverly written, the performances are excellent, and you rapidly engage in the social dynamics of this merry group of friends. The first half documents the rise, and obviously, you're expecting the fall. But, it never really comes, and that is where the movie gets frustrating. There are glimpses for instance that Martin had something darker in him from the start and that this alcoholic binge is just a façade that will be his downfall. But, there a never real adverse effects to the characters actions and we never get there. Drinking in the day time has mostly positive effects.Even when they increase the dosage they don't really suffer the consequences. The sequence where they get poop faced is not nearly as transgressive or humiliating enough. One guy gets yelled at by his ever-nagging wife, and Martin wakes up on his neighbour's lawn. It needed a scene of a real low point like one them wakes up at the hospital or they forget to turn off the stove and burn the house down. It needed to go full Trailer Park Boys Jim Lahey.In the second half, the story that was about a man's middle-life crisis turns into high-school drama. It is not necessarily bad, but it comes out of nowhere and is not nearly as riveting. The characters face low-points that ultimately are rather painlessly resolved and feels hollow. There is something of a disconnect with the beginning of the movie that felt more loaded and subversive. The character that was the least developed and had the less to lose abruptly dies without a real reason leading to it. Everyone rekindles with his or her wives and children; it is a missed opportunity for genuine catharsis.I feel that it would have benefited of following a more generic structure where Martin's tendencies lead him to self-destruct. That's what the narrative needed, a man who immolates himself through an addiction. I liked it, but I wanted to love it.

Review title: Vinterberg and Mads - a killer duo
Review_body:
Another achievement from director Thomas Vinterberg, it's been an absolute delight discovering multi national films, this is coming from someone who for a long time got stuck with American movies.After seeing The Hunt from 2012 from the same director, I was automatically drawn to getting to know more of his work, fast forward to now and his most recent masterpiece "Druk" (Another Round - English title).
It tells a story of 4 high school teachers who seem to be experiencing what you could generically classify as a "middle life crisis" and decide to embark on an experiment based on a real life controversial theory, that the human being is born with a deficit of alcohol in their blood, so they decide to have a low level of alcohol ingested on a daily basis to test this out.First of all the movie is incredibly realistic, both the student and the teachers depiction as well as their relationships and personal lives are so naturally brought to the screen you almost feel you are actually seeing a real life story, and this I believe is one of the strongest aspects of the movie, of course this is accomplished by the amazing direction skills as well as the acting department, specially from Mads Mikklesen himself.You get drawn to the story and the characters, and strangely enough the movie isn't either a celebration or a censorship for alcohol consumption, given that Nordic countries including Denmark, have a very different relationship with drinking and culturally they are indeed associated with high consumption of alcohol, the movie brings out the awfulness and the harm that it can cause to someone's life, but at the same time, it also showcases that in certain aspects or circumstances it can also be an enabler, specially when the source of joy doesn't come from the consumption itself, but instead, the consumption serves as a celebratory method to showcase your happiness in the first place.It's a controversial topic, and this is what I like about this director, you probably won't get such honest themes being depicted on your regular Hollywood movie, and this guy isn't afraid to show you his approach on a topic regardless if it's a taboo one or a controversial theme. Fantastic movie, I hope it gets the recognition it deserves on the coming award season.
